One thing you forget about lakeside water is that they often also contain leeches, and those little buggers will bite into you and suck blood, and only pop off when full, leaving you to bleed for hours afterwards. Can't just pull them off, as they leave their mouthparts behind, so you need to either pour boiling water on them, or use some petroleum based solvent to make them let go. Generally I used to just carry Dettol, as it will both disinfect and make them let go when applied neat, though it does sting a little. Plus avoid the edges of the lake where they are most common, and use a wetsuit to keep them away from the more interesting parts of the body.

For those freaked out about swimming in a little pee, consider how much cleaner a swimming pool is than a lake, river, sea, or ocean. One of these things is clear enough to see through, has disinfectant already in it, and the others all have living things in them, eating, peeing, pooping, as well as decaying plant and animal matter (dead things) decomposing.

Unless someone has a UTI, how is urine NOT sterile? Take the worlds most advanced water filtration system, and compare it to the human kidney, and the human kidney will out perform it for purity every time. Your blood should already be bacteria free unless you're dying of sepsis, and your kidneys are dumping out salts, water, and nitrogen compounds, not dumping bacteria and living cells. In fact most of the chemicals in urine can be re-created in a test tube using chemistry without involving anything living. The fact that urea could be synthesized as well as being naturally in urine was one of the most important discoveries in organic chemistry, proving that the chemistry of life, was identical to the chemistry we had already been using in non living things.

Hank, chloramine is in our drinking water. If you introduced liquid chlorine to a municipal well storage it would be so diluted by the end of the line, the water could become stagnant. Ammonia is added to make chloramine because it is a stable suspension which flows to the end of the line to keep sanitary conditions at all times and distances from the municipal supply. You fill your pool with regular city water. The amount of ammonia you urinate is so small, you would need hundreds of gallons of urine to make a difference depending how big the pool is.
